note.body:
I tracked down the problem to [podcasts-data/src/models/new_episodes.rs:239](https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/podcasts/blob/master/podcasts-data/src/models/new_episode.rs#L239) where `url_cleaner()` on enclosure elements. The [url_cleaner](https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/podcasts/blob/master/podcasts-data/src/utils.rs#L120) function explicitly removes the query strings needed to download the episodes successfully.

When I changed `Position::AfterPath` to `Position::AfterQuery` in url_cleaner, the correct url is added to the db and the episodes download.

Would keeping the query string break other podcasts?

I tried it out on a flatpak build of master and get improved but still broken behaviour:

# Current behavior

* Episode audio plays
* Image pops up in window
* Skipping 10s or seeking causes the audio to stop playing until episode is restarted

# Expected behaviour

* Skipping moves to the correct time in the episode and playback continues
* Not sure about the image. Seems to be part of a WIP

# Additional information

* The only related output on stderr is `podcasts_gtk::app: An error notification was triggered: The media player was unable to execute an action.` when closing the window that pops up. Doesn't seem relevant for the playback issues.

note.body:
There are more recent builds of Podcasts available under CI/CD as artifacts. However a build for master hasn't been produced in a while (the project seems to have moved to a different build system so I assume there's some kinks getting worked out there).

If you've downloaded a flatpak you can install it by double clicking the file. It should open in Gnome Software and give the option to install. In my case Gnome Software was acting up so I used `flatpak install <path-to-flatpak-file>`.

Launching from the command line shows stderr, so `flatpak run org.gnome.Podcasts.Devel` will run the builds installed from CI/CD or `flatpak run org.gnome.Podcasts` to run the stable version (if its installed).

I've attached my build of master if you want something more recent than whats available in CI/CD

[org.gnome.Podcasts.Devel_cf644d50.flatpak](/uploads/8491af5fa9bbdc2ff0ede4a58d52014b/org.gnome.Podcasts.Devel_cf644d50.flatpak)

> most users will have a much better out-of-the-box experience 

Can't agree with this statement. IBUS is very hard to use and have compatibility issues with many programs when input Chinese. IBUS will eat or double my inputs randomly. The first time I tried fcitx, I immediately switch to fcitx.

> NetworkManager

So is this one, which has very limited functions, and take like hundreds of years to stable.
This one troubles me a lot, I'd rather edit /etc/network/interfaces under debian.

> A couple of years ago we took a strategic decision to rather pick lower-level components and integrate well with them, instead of trying to create lowest-common-denominator abstractions over a range of alternatives.

In my opinion, you just pick a easy way with less effort, and left the pain to other maintainers who want to integrate their alternatives into GNOME.

note.body:
Hi Milan,

Thanks so much for pointing out that it could be done via File > New > Mail Accounts using "Exchange Web Services" as the Server Type. The account was added successfully and Mail, Tasks, Address Books and Notes all seem to be working correctly.

When I initially moved to Evolution, I only had mail working but required the Tasks, Address Books and Notes. I then found the evolution-ews package, but only ever setup the account via GOA. Over time I probably forgot that the evolution-ews packages adds a new Server Type in Evolution itself.

Regarding the Offline Address Book, I discussed it with the administrators at the time and we came to an agreement that it's not really required for us. I think by default, it's not automatically configured in Exchange 2019 if configured on-premise.

I suppose this is a bug in GOA itself then. Would you like to me file a new bug report under GOA, or will this issue be reassigned to that project?

Thanks again!

note.body:
Maybe with filtering on the size of available artwork, with too small image available equalling to no image at all, so the original plain background ? Although IMO the 2nd image, ableit obviously not ideal, is still nicer than a white or blurry background. 

And also The Audio DB allows to upload fanarts, so this could be a workaround too, manually helping them with the artists they're lacking data from, I did it myself with this for example : https://www.theaudiodb.com/artist/139752 .

It's a quick and easy process, and BTW now only allow 1280x720p or 1920x1080p resolutions. 

Also, if the fanarts are displayed, I think it would then be visually nicer to reduce the size and move the album art to the bottom, so that it doesn't hide the fanart.

PS: Re-reading myself I wonder if I might not sound demanding and arrogant, but it's not the case at all, I am very grateful to the work you put into Lollypop, and admiring your reactivity and kindness to my messages :smile:  I would love to help, but I have no knowledge of how to work with the .ui files ( I tried, and pathetically failed using Glade... ) I would gladly help with the Python part though ! :smile: :snake:

note.body:
The gold linker is required if you want to run it with asan. Otherwise it's pretty straightforward, install cargo-afl, create a binary target like the one above with `afl = 0.4` and the fuzzed library in the Cargo.toml. `cargo afl build` to build it and add instrumentation.

`mkdir in` and put a few small xml/svg files (the smaller the better because it needs to be fast to process). I also have a dict of xml/css specific keywords. Then do `cargo afl fuzz -x dict -i in -o out ../path/to/built/binary`

events.target_title: Wacom touchpad does not rotate along with "left-handed" tablet setting

note.body:
If I might add to the conversation.
I don't know if you're overthinking the problem. I have a Wacom Bamboo 16FG and an "easy fix" for me is to set the rotation of the Wacom touch-pad to half by using `xsetwacom set "Wacom Bamboo 16FG 4x5 Finger touch" Rotate half`.

Changing the tablet to left handed mode in the settings app only changes the values of `xsetwacom get "Wacom Bamboo 16FG 4x5 Pen stylus" Rotate` and `xsetwacom get "Wacom Bamboo 16FG 4x5 Pen eraser" Rotate` to `half`. So I need to set the Finger Touch rotation by using the command from above.
When changing the orientation for the Wacom touch-pad, the orientation for my mouse touch-pad from the laptop stays the same. So there seems to be no interference when also setting the rotation of the Wacom touch-pad to half.
So this actually is the last case @whot proposed. As long as this is not implemented, the workaround is setting the orientation of the touchpad with the xf86-input-wacom driver as I described in the beginning.

If you're already looked at it from this perspective I'm sorry to bother you, but maybe some people will find it helpful to use this workaround.

events.target_title: Other Locations kills navigation history

note.body:
So I did some research on this and maybe this is super obvious to the other developers but the reason the history gets cleared is because when you switch to `Other Locations` a new slot (`NautilusOtherLocationsWindowSlot`) is being created and set as the active slot which in turn calls the `sync_location_widgets` function on the window and thus disables the back button since there is no initial navigation history in said slot.

So I guess one approach would be to move the navigation history lists out of the window slot type into a dedicated module and keep them around during the back and forth between multiple slots.

Thoughts?

events.target_title: meson: add back default_driver option

note.body:
I stumbled across this the other day.

We have an ARM system with both a closed Mali driver stack and mesa installed, and we recently updated it from an old version of GNOME (before it carried cogl and clutter internally).

Previously the cogl package would be built with the default driver option, which would cause cogl applications to start with GLESv2, using the mali stack and running "fast".

Now we have libmutter-cogl built from packaging containing this patch.  It sets the cogl default driver using vestigial code, but libmutter-clutter overrides that default, so this patch becomes meaningless and has no effect - GLX + gl3 is tried first, which for us means software rendering (not fast enough to use).

The patch does indeed "add back" something that existed in cogl before mutter forked a copy, but not in a usable way for mutter, the only user of libmutter-cogl.

Functionally there is a difference between setting a default and completely disabling one of the choices, so the old default driver behaviour isn't exactly the same as disabling GLX completely (though for my specific use case disabling GLX is sufficient).

I do have a patch that adds a clutter default driver option and re-orders clutter's hard coded list of drivers to try to place it first, but if the way forward is "just disable GLX/OpenGL" it's not worthwhile to share...

Anyway, tl;dr:
mutter doesn't obey the "default driver" option like cogl did a long time ago
debian packaging tries to add it back, but doesn't quite succeed

Where does the bug exist - mutter or debian - and is there anything I can do to help fix it? :)

color temperature - original temperature confused with intended temperature
color temperature - original temperature confused with intended temperature

note.body:
Dear lillollo,

You are right in what you wrote. But there remains the wrong wording, because the concept of "Warm Colors" and "Color temperature" are confused.

Warmer Colors mean lower Kelvins! Most of the gimp users know this and every serious graphic designer or photographer knows this for sure. Watch the settings of your own Computer monitor in front of you and you will see that the wide spread standard concept of defining warm/cold colors is the the black body model. I strongly suggest, that gimp adheres to this de facto standard used world wide. 

I agree, this issue can be seen as a non bug. By Definition a bug is, when the software does not perform as intended. If the software does as intended but the intention is wrong, then the software is not buggy. Then the mistake lies in the conception. And that's exactly what happened here. I wouldn't have filed a bug, if the sliders would go from 0 to 100% of "redish", instead of a "temperature" in the range of 1000 to 12000, which clearly refers to the black body model (which is presumably used in the algorithm anyway). 

Thank you very much for your response, it was prompt and concise. And it is absolutely okay for me, that we don't quite agree in this detail. 

Peace!

events.target_title: Python plugins are not loaded
Python plugins are not loaded

note.body:
After days of research on this problem, I finally find it is caused by `zlib1.dll`

When `gimp.pyd` is imported, Gimp (or python?) tries to load this dll from `{gimp_installation_dir}\32\lib\gimp\2.0` first. And not found obviously because the file is located in `{gimp_installation_dir}\32\bin`. Then the process loads the dll from `SysWOW64` folder and got a module with lower version.

I can fix this problem by copying `zlib1.dll` from `32\bin` into `SysWOW64`, but I still have no idea why gimp will search the dll from `32\lib\gimp\2.0`? The folder is not listed in any environment variables at all.

events.target_title: Compiler warning when initializing property with constructor of implementation of interface with abstract property
Compiler warning when initializing property with constructor of implementation of interface with abstract property

note.body:
@gavr123456789 The issue you are linking to is related to Vala not using `const` keyword in generated C code the same way as the C code does. This is not necessarily an issue if Vala is aware of ownership and so on anyway (which it is supposed to be). You can compile with `-Wno-discarded-qualifiers` to hide this warning if you trust that all bindings that you are using are indeed correct.

While this issue does not cause any issues in this example (due to how vala generates property accessors), it may cause issues when having c bindings in place, that are not strictly following best practices for gtype/gobject code.

Evince 3.32 on Fedora 30 does not search cyrillic text
Evince 3.32 on Fedora 30 does not search cyrillic text

note.body:
Hello, Nelson!
Here is a simple pdf file with a text in Russian and English. Yesterday I found out that Evince 3.32 from Fedora official repository (installed by default in the system)doesn't want to search any cyrillic text (written in the Russian language). It perfectly searches a text in English and numbers. And by the way I don't see a checkbox "case sensitive" in the Search bar.
But! Yesterday, after my report here, I installed Evince 3.32 from Flatpak repository, and this version (from Flatpak) searches both English text and Russian!
So the situation is: the version installed by default in Fedora 30 doesn't search any russian text but the one from Flatpak repository does it well.

Excuse me for my bad English. ;)

[simpleFile.pdf](/uploads/654d0a57cb6ea3c62218737c6c2bf099/simpleFile.pdf)

events.target_title: Add a plugin system

note.body:
This is awesome!! Yeah, this is one of most wanted feature!
Today I was very angry due to unable to find any mail tool that will cover all my needs, and I decided to create one by myself :face_palm: . Then I made one last attempt to find out list of available best mail clients: Mailspring, Hiri, Evolution and so on. Evolution is free and has all that I need, but it's very often works incorrectly (everybody tried to use Ctrl+Z :laughing: ).

Well, I want to tell - Geary is the best one, but it's mail client only. If the feature to attach plugins will be introduced, then the community will be able to develop plugins like Calendar, Contacts, etc.

note.body:
I ran Entry Completion program from gtk3-demo and didn't get any sort of
crash going on. It all seemed to work perfectly. I also installed libasan
and ran Evolution as you suggested and it popped up with the address
pre-filled. But if I tried to write in a new address and tab complete, I
got the same crash as before with this being the output:

(evolution:18595): Gdk-CRITICAL **: 16:17:01.218:
gdkdisplay-wayland.c:1402: Unable to create Cairo image surface: invalid
value (typically too big) for the size of the input (surface, pattern, etc.)
AddressSanitizer:DEADLYSIGNAL

Dockerfile is enclosed below. place the dockefile inside the repo. 

```dockerfile
# build with ``sudo docker build -t gimp_help_builder``
# run with ``sudo docker run --name builder -v /path/to/gimp/repo/:/home/ubuntu -i -t gimp_help_builder``
# cd to repo
# ``./autoconf.sh --without-gimp``
# ``make``

FROM ubuntu:18.04
WORKDIR /home/ubuntu

RUN apt-get update \
&& apt-get install -qqy --no-install-recommends \

automake docbook2odf pkg-config make xsltproc dblatex gawk libxml2 libxml2-utils \
graphviz pngnq pngcrush gettext python-libxml2 docbook-xsl \

imagemagick \ # not sure, jpg to png still fails
fonts-freefont-ttf \
texlive-lang-spanish \
texlive-lang-european \
texlive-lang-german \

ENTRYPOINT ["/bin/bash"]```

events.target_title: Can't paste from Windows clipboard

note.body:
Unfortunately in the latest GIMP 2.10.10 (on Windows 10 Home, version 1803, build 17134.753) I'm still encountering issues while pasting into GIMP from XnView MP version 0.93.1 64bits (Mar 6 2019). I'm assuming since the two issues 

Does not work: copy from XnViewMP, paste into GIMP
Workaround: copy from XnViewMP, paste into Paint, copy again, paste into GIMP.

I looked at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/1359, and I can't quite tell whether the issue described is exactly the same. But even if it is, the problem persists.

I did some digging into clipboard data details using [Nirsoft's Inside Clipboard](http://www.nirsoft.net/utils/inside_clipboard.html). I'm using a 100x100 PNG image flattened to RGB (because Paint does not support transparency), so 30000 bytes of raw image data plus maybe some headers depending on format. Some of my findings:

- Paint places 2 copies into the clipboard. By clipboard section index:

  2. CF_DIB, 32768 bytes. Looks like the size is a bit off, being exactly 32 KiB. Data indeed shows some rubbish at the end, apparently this is fine.
  3. CF_BITMAP, 0 bytes
  4. CF_DIBV5, 30124 bytes

- XnViewMP copies the image into the clipboard in several formats. Both "CF_DIB" and "CF_DIBV5" are in the list, but many more. I'll name a few below, including their index. Note that the image file path is also put into the clipboard, in multiple formats.

  1. CF_DIB, 30040 bytes
  7. image/png, 3335 bytes
  8. image/bmp, 30054 bytes

  [...]

  20. CF_BITMAP, 0 bytes
  21. CF_DIBV5, 30124 bytes

- For comparison, I also copied the same image from GIMP to check what it puts into the clipboard itself. Result: 5 formats, indexed as follows:

  1. image/x-xcf, 6664 bytes
  2. PNG, 3537 bytes
  3. CF_DIB, 30040 bytes
  4. CF_DIBV5, 30124 bytes
  5. CF_BITMAP, 0 bytes

Not sure how GIMP accesses the clipboard, but it seems odd that providing more redundancy in image data in the clipboard (as XnViewMP does) results in GIMP telling me that there is no image data in the clipboard...

Attached are the clipboard contents from my trials, in a format understood by the mentioned InsideClipboard tool (load and hit the refresh button to see its contents), as well as the source image and a clipboard copy from the transparent version:
- Original image, with transparency: ![icons8-gimp-filled-100](/uploads/03901ed6ea05ec577e8fffc14eb1d081/icons8-gimp-filled-100.png)
- Flattened image: ![icons8-gimp-filled-100-flat](/uploads/7008d4ba83b9599d59b66e373b8f2ce3/icons8-gimp-filled-100-flat.png)
- Flattened image copied from XnViewMP: [png-without-transparency-copied-from-xnviewmp.clp](/uploads/576b739a855db71fb156d2cae6cdc3d4/png-without-transparency-copied-from-xnviewmp.clp)
- Flattened image copied from Paint: [png-without-transparency-copied-from-paint.clp](/uploads/87490b76a99557b2ddfb66a15b76f762/png-without-transparency-copied-from-paint.clp)
- Flattened image copied from GIMP: [png-without-transparency-copied-from-gimp.clp](/uploads/3a8fd2d6dcfb387190f46b2b3b9a64ef/png-without-transparency-copied-from-gimp.clp)
- Original image (with transparency) copied from XnViewMP: [png-with-transparency-copied-from-xnviewmp.clp](/uploads/45549ad0893809103e7d1f3eff44de17/png-with-transparency-copied-from-xnviewmp.clp)

events.target_title: generic-player: create directory when syncing playlist
playlists created on devices have wrong path specification

note.body:
I have started looking at this.

The playlist file is made by adding each song with its full URI to a playlist with `totem_pl_playlist_append()` and `totem_pl_playlist_set()`. Then calling `totem_pl_parser_save()`. These functions are from `totem-pl-parser` not `rhythmbox`.

In `totem_pl_parser_save()`, for each file `totem_pl_parser_relative()` gets called. This calls `g_file_get_relative_path()` in glib. So if the song file is within the parent directory of the playlist, then the song URI is replaced with a relative path.

A possible solution would be to allow `totem_pl_parser_relative()` or `g_file_get_relative_path()` to use `..` parent directories. I am not sure if this would always be wanted. Maybe there could be a `force_relative` option?

note.body:
Thanks for comments. I shall try to resolve.

Do you prefer using multiple `GError`s, or should I use one and call `g_clear_error()` after printing the message?

Do you think its OK for the function to continue in these error cases? From a user point of view I think its ok to get a the "Playlist save failed: Error creating directory ..." followed by "Playlist save failed: Error opening file ...". The alternative is to return early (which requires calling the cleanup), a goto to jump to the cleanup, or putting the rest of the function in the else block.

events.target_title: Plug-in crashed: "help-browser.exe"
Feature Request: Tray Icon

note.body:
Hi, can someone clarify why this request was closed in favor of a bug report that's been marked obsolete? 

I would like to use Geary same way I use slack/skype, both of them have an icon that 1) indicates app is running, cos not everyone likes various clients to autostart and 2) indicates if there are unread messages at a glance, without having to open notification pane, autohidden doc, etc.

events.target_title: Feature Request: Tray Icon

note.body:
Hello @mjog Sad to hear that, but thanks for reply nonetheless.

The plugin system, `Always watch for new email` option, and unity indicator will not solve my problem. More specifically each of them have caveats:

Unread message counts are displayed on the icon for application in dock, which I autohide. Even when I didn't autohide it I used `Dash to panel` gnome shell extension which didn't display counts. So it in no way gives me an indicator about unread messages at a glance.

`Always watch for new email` option apparently isn't honored when I press ctrl+q. It would not be a problem, in fact transmission/slack/skype works exactly same way, BUT these applications do offer an icon in tray which unambiguously indicates if app is running or not. With Geary I have to constantly double check if I haven't closed the invisible background process by accident.

Plugin system is an interesting idea, but I have no high hopes for it after my experiences with Thunderbird plugin system. For example, I tried getting Thunderbird to display tray icon on fresh install of Ubuntu 18.04. First I found that original plugins `FireTray` and `MinimizeToTray revived` are no longer working with TB 60+. Then I found there is a new 60+ compatible plugin called `MinimizeToTray reanimated`. Installed it - no go, plugin does not load. After searching found that I needed an older version from developers page instead of thunderbird plugin page for older ubuntu TB, which did load plugin, but no icon appeared. Then figured out I needed gnome shell extension `Tray icons`, icon finally appeared, but surprise - It does not show any difference when inbox is empty or new email arrives, ultimately making whole installation not worth the effort.

So that's why I asked why was the original proposal for tray icon closed, in favor of features that do not address the issue, or rather address the issue only for users who use geary in a specific way - that is always have dock visible, never press ctrl+q, and do double checks once in a while if process did not close by accident.

events.target_title: New Downloaded Font's not loading

note.body:
I am using GIMP 2.10

I had to do some digging with multiple attempts at "Chess of Confusion"'s work-a-round --
I had to go to:
*Local Disk C* **->** *Program Files* **->** *GIMP 2* **->** *Share* **->** *GIMP* **->** *2.0* **->** *Fonts*

and paste all my font files there for *GIMP 2.10* to register them

hope this might help someone out there

events.target_title: GTK_WINDOW_POPUP works differently in x11 and wayland.
GTK_WINDOW_POPUP works differently in x11 and wayland.

note.body: `gtk_window_set_accept_focus (GTK_WINDOW (window), FALSE)` also has focus in the wayland backend. I want a window that has no focus.

events.target_title: GTK_WINDOW_POPUP works differently in x11 and wayland.
GTK_WINDOW_POPUP works differently in x11 and wayland.

note.body:
It is important to create a window that can not have focus for CJK users.  
Consider input methods such as on-screen keyboard, candidate window, preedit window for CJK developers and users.

Do you know `onboard`?

https://packages.debian.org/buster/onboard

`onboard` does not have focus in x11 environment but It has focus in wayland environment. So we can't use these applications in the wayland environment. Who made wayland, xwayland, backend? Why don't you consider CJK users and developers?

If we can not create a window that can not have focus in the wayland environment, CJK users will not be able to use Linux desktop. This is a very serious problem.

events.target_title: Update ko.po
GTK_WINDOW_POPUP works differently in x11 and wayland.

note.body:
I was ignorant. You are right. I'm sorry.  
I know X11, but I don't know how to approach the problem in Wayland.  
The same is true for libgtk-4.

note.body:
Okay so I think I understand a little more now.

If I uninstall Wintab, reinstall, launch GIMP, draw something, then erase it then it'll work normally. I can even LIFT MY ERASER and the paintbrush settings for my eraser stay there until I use a different pointer like the pen tip.

After that, if I draw again, my eraser will do what the top post does ^^ and the paintbrush settings for the eraser goes away immediately and switches to the pen tip even though I haven't used the pen tip yet.

Is there something weird going on here with timings? The issue seems like it's because gimp defaults back to the pen tip/nib immediately after the eraser is used whether the pen tip is being used or not. Is there a reason for that?
